text: [969.25-970.67] SPEAKER_02: Thank you very much.
[971.73-978.08] SPEAKER_02: I think I first want to echo and perhaps be a little bit more direct about what Director Catlin said.
[980.16-985.61] SPEAKER_02: We have bus routes in this system that don't qualify for the ADA service, but they're bus routes anyway.
[986.67-989.72] SPEAKER_02: There are commuter routes and I
[989.7-998.22] SPEAKER_02: would not vote personally for a change that would cut off the people who live within three quarters of a mile of those routes.
[998.27-1004.69] SPEAKER_02: So at least for me, you guys want to get this through, you're going to need to change that because it's just a matter of basic equity.
[1004.73-1006.29] SPEAKER_02: Otherwise, Peggy has like
[1006.96-1010.69] SPEAKER_02: two places in our district that get service and that's just not reasonable.
[1010.71-1013.84] SPEAKER_02: There are a lot of older folks that live up in those areas.
[1014.82-1022.05] SPEAKER_02: I think the second issue that I have with what's being proposed is that the needs of
[1022.67-1031.73] SPEAKER_02: you know, not call it rural, but mountainous Jefferson County when it comes to AOD are very different than the needs of central Denver.
[1032.53-1042.49] SPEAKER_02: The trips I can get to most places that I need to go, you know, in terms of grocery stores, medical, et cetera, in a $15 Uber.
[1042.47-1051.49] SPEAKER_02: You know, I don't think there's anywhere that you can get to for 15 bucks in Peggy's district or yours exactly.
[1053.64-1058.55] SPEAKER_02: But creating a system where the trip cap is 40 bucks doesn't work for me.
[1058.66-1064.07] SPEAKER_02: Creating a trip cap where it's 15 bucks doesn't work for the people in her district.
[1064.15-1075.81] SPEAKER_02: It strikes me that the right approach would be to have different levels of financial cap and different levels of trip cap to go along with them and let people pick.
[1075.93-1077.87] SPEAKER_02: You want 60 trips at
[1079.97-1082.54] SPEAKER_02: You want 50 trips at $20 per.
[1082.96-1085.91] SPEAKER_02: You want 40 trips at $30 per.
[1086.57-1087.67] SPEAKER_02: Depends on where you live.
[1087.69-1089.63] SPEAKER_02: Depends on the types of trips you're going to be taking.
[1089.69-1099.69] SPEAKER_02: But making people all fit into one size is either going to leave her people paying $20 for every single trip that they take.
[1099.67-1108.77] SPEAKER_02: or it's going to put people in my district in a reduced number of rides because very few trips are going to cost $20 or $25.
[1109.03-1111.08] SPEAKER_02: So those are my two pieces of feedback.
[1111.1-1111.4] SPEAKER_02: Thank you.
[1113.58-1114.36] SPEAKER_09: Thank you, Secretary.
[1115.16-1115.83] SPEAKER_09: Director Ruscha.
[1120.48-1121.16] SPEAKER_17: Thank you, Mr. Chair.
[1122.32-1126.73] SPEAKER_17: So I just wanted to offer a bit of context.
[1126.89-1131.79] SPEAKER_17: And the general manager, please interrupt me if I'm framing this wrong.
[1132.17-1138.46] SPEAKER_17: But the conversation that we're having tonight is a framework of a potential path forward.
[1139.14-1145.53] SPEAKER_17: And because of our OSS meeting went so long,
[1145.51-1152.03] SPEAKER_17: we weren't able to get to through the discussion and that also I think impacted our ability to have some interim discussions.

[1152.07-1175.34] SPEAKER_17: So I just want folks to you know keep keep an open mind to what staff is saying and definitely share that feedback because we're on a timeline but also just recognize that well and please if I'm saying the strong introduction but what is being presented is a concept framework and so we want so we'll get more feedback and then of course staff is going to be working very closely
[1175.66-1183.09] SPEAKER_17: with our existing customers and advocacy organizations to make further refinements and give us some more stuff to look at.
[1183.15-1190.29] SPEAKER_17: So I hope I didn't speak out of turn, but I just wanted to offer that for context.

[1191.03-1203.53] SPEAKER_17: And I'm also listening and taking notes and I know staff is, so I would just urge if anyone has thoughts one way or another, please share them tonight since we are also on
[1203.81-1207.76] SPEAKER_17: timeline with our existing partners and those contracts as well.
[1207.8-1208.16] SPEAKER_17: Thank you.
[1209.28-1209.92] SPEAKER_08: Thank you, Director.
[1210.72-1211.41] SPEAKER_08: Director Larson.
[1215.05-1215.49] SPEAKER_06: Thank you.
[1215.6-1217.94] SPEAKER_06: I just have a question for Ms.
[1217.98-1218.44] SPEAKER_06: Vallejos.
[1219.74-1223.25] SPEAKER_06: So I saw I seen one of those slot these slides that it says there's
[1223.54-1232.07] SPEAKER_06: In December of 2024, there were about 2,900 total active customers of access on demand.
[1233.13-1238.29] SPEAKER_06: So there were 2,900 people, roughly, who used it in all of December.
[1239.07-1239.57] SPEAKER_06: Is that right?
[1240.91-1243.52] SPEAKER_20: I know that would be for the year, I believe.
[1244.6-1245.28] SPEAKER_06: Let me just.
[1245.96-1250.95] SPEAKER_06: So 2,900 people used this service for the whole year.
[1252.58-1265.27] SPEAKER_06: And so I guess what I'm trying to just understand is, if we were going to spend, say, $10 million or $15 million on 2,900 people,
[1265.74-1270.81] SPEAKER_06: What do we think the equivalent is for just our regular riders?
[1271.11-1272.05] SPEAKER_06: Do we have any guess?
[1272.67-1275.03] SPEAKER_06: I mean, I know people have different ridership.

[1275.07-1289.43] SPEAKER_06: If we have a million customers a year and it's the majority of our budget, I'm just trying to get a sense of how the per-person spend for a regular rider compares to the per-person spend for access on demand.
[1291.71-1293.76] SPEAKER_20: Go ahead, Deborah.
[1295.54-1299.05] SPEAKER_16: So if I can, Mr. Chair, and thank you, Director Larsen, for the question.
[1299.31-1301.75] SPEAKER_16: I would not want us to conjecture and speculate.
[1301.81-1303.62] SPEAKER_16: We could double back and give you those numbers.
[1304.52-1310.25] SPEAKER_16: As we talk about, you use the term regular writer, you're talking about those that are using fixed route service.
[1310.27-1313.41] SPEAKER_16: I just want to be clear and intentional with the language we're using going forward.
[1313.39-1322.19] SPEAKER_16: So we need to assess that because it's a different level of service because with fixed route bus, we're not providing curb to curb service.
[1322.53-1326.45] SPEAKER_16: And so we can double back and share that information with the board.
[1327.39-1331.52] SPEAKER_16: But I think it wouldn't be fruitful for us to guesstimate because this is critically important.
[1331.88-1337.39] SPEAKER_16: But as we come back and we have some guidance, we could provide that detailed information, if you will.
[1337.79-1338.13] SPEAKER_16: Thank you.
[1340.11-1341.17] SPEAKER_16: Thank you.
[1342.51-1344.59] SPEAKER_10: Any other directors comments?
[1344.61-1345.41] SPEAKER_09: Yeah, director Guzman.
[1346.35-1353.88] SPEAKER_05: So I am concerned with the aligning with the ADA for the service area.
[1356.37-1360.31] SPEAKER_05: District C is fairly blessed with
[1360.71-1369.69] SPEAKER_05: multiple forms of transit and fixed route, where this is not a particular problem, but it is an issue in the suburban areas of the region.

[1370.13-1383.77] SPEAKER_05: And it is highly concerning that we would restrict it so much where people would be left off of the system that live within a quarter mile of a commuter bus and still not be able to access this.

[1386.26-1398.6] SPEAKER_05: I also think that as we proceed into the future after the demographers presentation to the finance and planning committee, a big concern will be our aging population in the region.
[1399.48-1404.62] SPEAKER_05: And it's a, you know, somebody said that this is a drop in the bucket for our budget.
[1405.85-1416.12] SPEAKER_05: Maybe right now, but eventually this is going to catch up with us, which is why we're having this conversation and access on demand and folks that are able to
[1416.45-1430.93] SPEAKER_05: or out of need, utilize this system, need to be considered as humans first and how we serve them, which is our mission, right?
[1430.95-1432.64] SPEAKER_05: They need connection as well.
[1433.11-1446.55] SPEAKER_05: and not every one of them will be able to jump from a, jump, roll, walk, shuffle to a fixed route form of transportation to get them to their destinations.
[1447.51-1454.08] SPEAKER_05: I have a question about the time on this, right?
[1454.54-1459.35] SPEAKER_05: If it's mirroring regular service provision for the whole region,
[1460.58-1468.37] SPEAKER_05: It kind of makes sense, but I would still be concerned for the reasons that emergencies don't happen on RTD schedule.
[1469.37-1478.38] SPEAKER_05: And so somebody who already has a specific need for this type of transportation usage might need to go to the doctor.
[1478.92-1481.61] SPEAKER_05: And what do they do if they're unable to drive?

[1482.13-1492.69] SPEAKER_05: And regular bus service is not something that they can use because the buses aren't running a two o'clock in the morning emergency room visit is not unheard of and not uncommon in anybody's life.
[1493.25-1496.01] SPEAKER_05: And yet what do we do to take care of those that are most vulnerable.
[1497.4-1500.64] SPEAKER_05: So for me, I would really want to see some clarity around
[1501.03-1502.05] SPEAKER_05: those two areas.
[1503.19-1508.7] SPEAKER_05: I am frankly less concerned about minimal difference of cost savings.
[1509.62-1512.14] SPEAKER_05: I mean, we're talking $5 million.
[1512.18-1518.3] SPEAKER_05: That's not really the top priority for me on that part.

[1518.68-1543.56] SPEAKER_05: right now it will eventually get there because this will likely continue to grow but I do want to make sure that we are basing ourselves in reality to serve the taxpayers needs and this is a need right this is not a desire as some of the other services we want to grow and create are this one is an actual need and so I want to be clear in my language on that and why I'm
[1544.57-1546.91] SPEAKER_05: depositing these comments within that framework.
[1547.26-1548.48] SPEAKER_05: So that would be my feedback.
[1548.5-1552.99] SPEAKER_05: I'd like to see something a little bit different on those two things, the service area and the time for service.
[1553.17-1553.48] SPEAKER_05: Thank you.
[1554.06-1554.76] SPEAKER_05: Thank you, Director.
[1555.44-1556.14] SPEAKER_05: Director Harwick.
[1557.14-1559.42] SPEAKER_04: Well, thank you, Director Guzman.
[1559.44-1561.75] SPEAKER_04: I'm just going to pretty much replicate everything you just said.
[1561.77-1571.16] SPEAKER_04: I represent Arvada, and Arvada is actually the fastest growing aging population.
[1571.36-1572.56] SPEAKER_04: However, I said that.
[1572.64-1573.51] SPEAKER_04: I'm not sure I said it right.
[1574.17-1579.64] SPEAKER_04: And a lot of our service is not in the areas where we have those aging people.
[1580.2-1582.84] SPEAKER_04: So I'd really like to see
[1583.39-1585.44] SPEAKER_04: just the boundary kept the same.
[1585.56-1590.48] SPEAKER_04: I'm also really again with director Guzman keeping it as a full 24 seven.

[1590.5-1606.9] SPEAKER_04: I just like I have a friend in a wheelchair and I just think about her trying like if she didn't live where she lived if she lived where I live she would have such a difficult time getting you know around her community and I won't just
[1607.41-1612.9] SPEAKER_04: especially like if the service is outside of that time period, it's just precluding her life.

[1612.96-1624.1] SPEAKER_04: And I know we don't all have these, the same abilities when we're riding the bus, but for a person with disability that's blind or in a wheelchair, I think that we can sort of extend them the grace that they deserve.
[1625.01-1627.45] SPEAKER_04: I also would like to see the cap stay at 60.

[1627.61-1640.82] SPEAKER_04: I think that, again, I know that it's a, you know, less than 10% of the population go above the 50 rides, but I think it's still like that's, we're giving them access to a free and full life.
[1641.88-1650.07] SPEAKER_04: And I think if we are gonna go with the 650, I think that that to me is fine, but I also think that it would be imperative that we really,

[1650.05-1677.56] SPEAKER_04: put out the live program and let let those writers know That there is another option like there's always with someone the other day she Lives about three miles away from where she works and you know She can afford it, but just barely and she didn't know about the live program So I think that there's we're missing an opportunity there specifically with these With these writers so and then my last one is just a request is it possible to get a map of

[1677.54-1692.32] SPEAKER_04: like sort of like a density map of where AOD is like highly being used to sort of go with that, like thinking about, you know, West Jefferson County versus central Denver, just kind of see what that looks like.
[1692.42-1699.61] SPEAKER_04: Obviously we want to anonymize the data, but I think it's sort of just would be interesting for us to know where the sort of hotspots of usage are.
[1699.64-1700.91] SPEAKER_04: Thank you.
[1700.95-1701.67] SPEAKER_09: Thank you, Director Harwick.

[1703.48-1721.9] SPEAKER_16: Yes, Director Harwick, if I understood you correctly, because I'm taking copious notes here, you are in support for all intents and purposes of what I hear, the modification of scenario one, keeping it at 60 trips with 650 and then one information relative to what the current usage is from a geographic vantage point.
[1722.4-1723.18] SPEAKER_16: Okay, thank you.
[1724.44-1725.06] SPEAKER_04: Thank you.
[1725.08-1729.14] SPEAKER_04: Yeah, but I also want to keep the service areas the same as they are today.
[1731.99-1732.29] SPEAKER_10: Excellent.
[1733.55-1735.49] SPEAKER_10: Director Nicholson, then Director Ruscha.
